metadata.description: Research data for fiscaljustice.com - All data points with source references

1A.notes: Base state rate; local rates add 0.5%-3.9% on top

WA state property tax avg effective rate
1A.notes: Varies 0.8%-1.2% by county with local levies
Two-tier system effective Jan 1 2025; deduction inflation-adjusted
WA Constitution Article VII; capital gains tax classified as excise tax

1A.data_point: WA sales tax expansion to services
1A.value: IT consulting, digital advertising, custom software, staffing, security, data processing

1B.data_point: ITEP Who Pays ranking for WA
1B.notes: Improved from #1 due to capital gains tax and Working Families Tax Credit
Avg income $18,600; down from 17.8% in prior edition
Avg income $2,077,500; up from 3% pre-capital gains tax
Lowest earners pay 3.4x the effective rate of top 1%

1B.notes: Main report with methodology and all state rankings

10% of General Fund; state levy only, excludes local

3A.data_point: WA K-12 annual funding gap (OSPI estimate)
3A.source_name: OSPI 2025-27 Budget Request / WA State Standard
3A.notes: Superintendent Reykdal's request: ~$1B special ed, $695M classified staff, $350M MSOC, remainder transportation & other gaps

3A.data_point: WA special education annual funding shortfall
3A.value: $435 million/year gap between state funding and district spending
3A.notes: Districts cover shortfall with local levy dollars; recent cap increases close <$20M of gap

3A.data_point: WA State PTA K-12 funding gap priorities
3A.value: Closing funding gaps in special ed, MSOC, transportation, and local effort assistance
3A.source_name: WA State PTA — Closing the Funding Gaps 2025-26
3A.notes: Legislative priority brief corroborating ~$3.7-4B annual gap estimate

3A.data_point: WA K-12 share of state general fund declining
3A.notes: K-12 funding not keeping pace with rising costs and enrollment needs

3A.value: $1B special ed + $695M staff pay + $350M MSOC + transportation
3A.notes: Detailed breakdown of the $3.7B request by category

3B.data_point: WA Fair Start for Kids Act total investment

3B.value: Up to 75% of state median income ($76,626/yr for family of 3)

3B.notes: ~27% avg statewide increase to cost-of-quality rates

3B.data_point: Only ~29% of children needing care served by licensed providers

3B.notes: Full-time center-based for all; actual would be lower with enrollment rates

3B.data_point: Center for American Progress early learning data
Annie E. Casey child population by age group

Progressive income tax, no sales tax; bottom 20% pay 8.2%, top 1% pay 9%

Baseline: WA state property tax revenue

Baseline: WA total taxable retail sales

5A.notes: Classified as excise tax; applies to stocks, bonds, business interests; excludes real estate and retirement

5A.data_point: WA capital gains tax FY2024 revenue
5A.source_name: WA Dept of Revenue News Release
5A.notes: Net payments as of June 2, 2025; 34% increase over FY2023 ($418.6M); 3,403 extensions pending

5A.data_point: WA capital gains tax deduction threshold
5A.notes: Standard deduction; only gains above this amount are taxed

5A.data_point: WA total long-term capital gains realized (all filers)
5A.notes: Federal long-term capital gains reported by WA filers; includes gains exempt from state tax (real estate, retirement)

5A.data_point: WA capital gains tax FY2022 revenue (first year)
5A.source_name: WA Dept of Revenue News Release
5A.notes: First year of tax; higher due to market conditions

5A.data_point: WA capital gains tax FY2023 revenue
5A.notes: Down from FY2022 due to market downturn; 34% below FY2024

5A.data_point: WA capital gains tax 2025 tier 2 rate
5A.notes: New tier added in 2025 legislation; gains up to $1M remain at 7%

5A.data_point: Estimated WA state-taxable capital gains base
5A.source_name: Derived from WA DOR revenue and IRS SOI
5A.notes: Back-calculated: $560.6M revenue / 7% rate ≈ $8B taxable base; total gains ~$17.8B but real estate, retirement, sub-threshold gains excluded

5B.data_point: WA DOR Wealth Tax Study — proposed rate and threshold
5B.value: 1% on financial intangible property above $250M per household
5B.source_name: WA Dept of Revenue Wealth Tax Study Final Report
5B.notes: Commissioned by WA Legislature; published November 2024

5B.data_point: WA DOR Wealth Tax Study — estimated annual revenue
5B.source_name: WA Dept of Revenue Wealth Tax Study Final Report
5B.notes: Estimated ~700 affected households; targets < 0.01% of Washingtonians

5B.data_point: WA DOR Wealth Tax Study — $100M threshold estimate
5B.source_name: WA Cities / WA DOR Wealth Tax Study
5B.notes: Governor's alternative proposal; broader reach than $250M threshold

5B.data_point: WA residents with net worth over $50M
5B.notes: Rapid growth in ultra-high-net-worth population in WA
More than 4x the state's $78B two-year operating budget; Bezos moved to FL in 2023
End of 2024; top 1% holds ~$55.8T, top 10% holds ~67% of total

5B.data_point: WA estimated total household net worth
5B.source_name: Derived from Fed Z.1 and BEA State GDP
5B.notes: Proportional estimate using WA GDP share ($785B / $25.5T national GDP); actual may be higher due to tech wealth concentration
Applied to WA estimate: top 1% ~$1.73T, top 10% ~$3.52T, bottom 50% ~$315B
